cards.name: Entirely Normal Armchair
cards.originalText:
During your turn, if Entirely Normal Armchair is in your hand, you may hide it on the battlefield.
{0}: Return Entirely Normal Armchair to its owner's hand. Only any opponent may activate this ability and only if they see Entirely Normal Armchair.
{2}, Sacrifice Entirely Normal Armchair: Destroy target attacking creature.

rulings.text: Entirely Normal Armchair must be in your hand for you to hide it on the battlefield. You can’t sneak it onto the battlefield from outside the game or from your library or from anywhere else.
It doesn’t have to be behind another card or item on the battlefield. In other words, you can hide it in plain sight. Easier to spot there though.

Any opponent can activate the middle ability, but only if they can identify where it is, even if they can’t literally see it. You can’t cover it with your hand to stop them from activating the ability, for example.

cards.text:

cards.name: Free-Range Chicken
cards.originalText: {1}{G}: Roll two six-sided dice. If both results are the same, Free-Range Chicken gets +X/+X until end of turn, where X is that result. If the total of those results is equal to any other total you have rolled this turn for this ability, sacrifice it. (For example, if you roll two 3s, it gets +3/+3. If you roll a 4 and a 2 for this ability later that turn, sacrifice it.)
cards.text: {1}{G}: Roll two six-sided dice. If both results are the same, Free-Range Chicken gets +X/+X until end of turn, where X is that result. If the total of those results is equal to any other total you have rolled this turn for this ability, sacrifice it. (For example, if you roll two 3s, it gets +3/+3. If you roll a 4 and a 2 for this ability later that turn, sacrifice it.)

cards.name: GO TO JAIL
cards.originalText:
When GO TO JAIL enters the battlefield, exile target creature an opponent controls until GO TO JAIL leaves the battlefield.
At the beginning of the upkeep of the exiled card's owner, that player rolls two six-sided dice. If they roll doubles, sacrifice GO TO JAIL.

rulings.text: If the two dice end up having the same result, that counts as having rolled doubles. For example, if you roll a 5 and a 6, but you use the ability of Snickering Squirrel to change the first die to a 6, you’ve rolled doubles.
If you end up rolling more than two dice for the last ability (for example, because of More or Less), you’ve rolled doubles if any two of those dice have the same result.

cards.text:
When GO TO JAIL enters the battlefield, exile target creature an opponent controls until GO TO JAIL leaves the battlefield.
At the beginning of the upkeep of the exiled card's owner, that player rolls two six-sided dice. If they roll doubles, sacrifice GO TO JAIL.

cards.flavorText: An accessory in every sense of the word.
cards.name: Goblin Haberdasher
cards.originalText: Menace (This creature can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.) Other creatures you control wearing hats in their art have menace.

rulings.text: A hat is a garment worn on the head that’s not part of another garment. Hoodies, for example, are not hats. Items that only cover the face and not the top of the head, such as a face mask, are also not hats.
The creature that the card represents must be wearing a hat to have menace. Other figures in the art wearing hats doesn’t count.

cards.text:
Menace (This creature can't be blocked except by two or more creatures.)

cards.name: Half-Squirrel, Half-
cards.originalText: Whenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield, Augment {G} ({G}, Reveal this card from your hand: Combine it with target host. Augment only as a sorcery.)

rulings.text: Creatures with augment don’t have a mana cost and can’t be cast.

Augment is an activated ability that you activate from your hand. To do so, reveal the card, choose a target host creature, and pay the augment cost. As this ability resolves, if the card with augment is still in your hand, put it onto the battlefield combined with the host creature.

Augment can (and usually does) change the name, card types, subtypes, rules text, and power/toughness. The combined creature will have (at least) two artists and may now have multiple colors. Anything covered up in the augment process doesn’t count, so ignore things to the left of the “metal bar” in the art of host creatures.
Augment can’t target creatures that aren’t host creatures.

The creature card with augment isn’t put onto the battlefield until the ability resolves. This means if the host is destroyed, the creature with augment stays in your hand. You can’t choose a different host, but you can activate augment again if there’s another host available.

You can’t activate augment unless there is a host creature on the battlefield. It doesn’t need to be yours. Note though that if you augment another player’s host creature, they control the combined creature.
You can’t put more than one augment card on a single host creature. Once a host creature is augmented, the host part gets covered up and it’s no longer a host creature.

cards.text:

Augment {G} ({G}, Reveal this card from your hand: Combine it with target host. Augment only as a sorcery.)

Augment can’t target creatures that aren’t host creatures.

The creature card with augment isn’t put onto the battlefield until the ability resolves. This means if the host is destroyed, the creature with augment stays in your hand. You can’t choose a different host, but you can activate augment again if there’s another host available.

You can’t activate augment unless there is a host creature on the battlefield. It doesn’t need to be yours. Note though that if you augment another player’s host creature, they control the combined creature.
You can’t put more than one augment card on a single host creature. Once a host creature is augmented, the host part gets covered up and it’s no longer a host creature.

cards.name: Infinity Elemental
cards.originalText: (This creature has INFINITE POWER.)

rulings.text: Infinite power is incalculable. Infinity Elemental will have the greatest power among creature on the battlefield, tied only with other Infinity Elementals. Gaining or losing power is meaningless to it, although effects that set its power to other numbers will still work.

If an Infinity Elemental you control gains lifelink and deals damage, you’ll then have infinite life. From that point on, your life total effectively can’t change. If you lose life, you’ll still be at infinite life. You can pay any amount of life and still be at infinite life. In fact, you can be hit by an opposing Infinity Elemental and still be at infinite life.

cards.text: (This creature has INFINITE POWER.)

cards.flavorText: Krark was the kind of goblin who'd lose his thumb in a wager and come right back with "Double or nothing!"
cards.name: Krark's Other Thumb
cards.originalText: If you would roll a die, instead roll two of those dice and ignore one of those results.

rulings.text: Krark’s Other Thumb works with any die you’re instructed or allowed to roll.
The ignored roll never happened as far as any other cards are concerned.
If you’re instructed to roll multiple dice, roll two for each one and choose which die to count.
Krark’s Other Thumb can apply to rerolls.

If the die roll includes some physical functionality, such as caring where the die lands, roll two dice following all instructions that apply to the die roll. You might need to use colored dice to keep each pair of dice clear so you can ignore one roll from each pair.

cards.text: If you would roll a die, instead roll two of those dice and ignore one of those results.

cards.name: Look at Me, I'm R&D
cards.originalText:
As Look at Me, I'm R&D comes into play, choose a number and a second number one higher or one lower than that number.
All instances of the first chosen number on permanents, spells, and cards in any zone are the second chosen number.
cards.text:
As Look at Me, I'm R&D enters the battlefield, choose a number and a second number one higher or one lower than the first number.
All instances of the first chosen number in the full text of each permanent, spell, and card in any zone are changed to the second chosen number.

cards.flavorText: No body is ready for this kind of power.
cards.name: Skull Saucer
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Skull Saucer enters the battlefield, destroy target creature and put your head on the table. Sacrifice Skull Saucer when your head stops touching the table.

rulings.text: You can still have Skull Saucer enter the battlefield and destroy a creature without putting your head on the table.
If you’re not playing on a table, putting your head on the playing surface will meet the requirements of the card.
Any part of your head, including your chin, will work.
If your opponent is playing with their head on the table, you can’t physically make them lift their head up. You can try and talk them into it.

cards.text:
Flying
When Skull Saucer enters the battlefield, destroy target creature and put your head on the table. Sacrifice Skull Saucer when your head stops touching the table.

cards.name: Slaying Mantis
cards.originalText: Just a second (As long as this spell is on the stack, players can't move cards on the battlefield.) Slaying Mantis enters the battlefield by being thrown from a distance of at least three feet. When Slaying Mantis enters the battlefield, it fights each creature an opponent controls that it touched as it entered.

rulings.text: Once Slaying Mantis has been declared as a spell, the just a second ability is immediately effective. All cards are locked into place on the battlefield.

If Slaying Mantis lands on multiple creatures, it will fight each of them simultaneously. For example, if it lands on a 3/3, a 4/4, and a 6/6, Slaying Mantis will deal 6 damage to each of them, destroying them all. At the same time, they deal a total of 13 damage to Slaying Mantis, destroying it.
If Slaying Mantis touches a creature an opponent controls midflight but doesn’t land on that creature, it will still fight it.
Slaying Mantis will fight creature tokens an opponent controls if it hits the object used to represent the token.

Just a second applies only if Slaying Mantis is being cast. If it enters the battlefield without being cast, players are free to move around their permanents. This includes midflight, resulting in a fun little game of dodgeball.
No matter how Slaying Mantis is entering the battlefield, opponents can’t interfere with Slaying Mantis itself.

cards.text:
Just a second (As long as this spell is on the stack, players can't move cards on the battlefield.)
Slaying Mantis enters the battlefield by being thrown from a distance of at least three feet.
When Slaying Mantis enters the battlefield, it fights each creature an opponent controls that it touched as it entered.

cards.flavorText: "In this line of work, you've got to know how to squirrel things away. Quite literally, in my case."
cards.name: Snickering Squirrel
cards.originalText: You may tap Snickering Squirrel to increase the result of a die any player rolled by 1.

rulings.text: You decide whether to use Snickering Squirrel’s ability after seeing the result of a die roll.
You can use the ability even if Snickering Squirrel the turn it enters the battlefield.
You can use the ability to produce results not normally possible. For example, you change the result of a six-sided die roll to a 7.
Multiple Snickering Squirrels can be used to affect a single die roll.

cards.text: You may tap Snickering Squirrel to increase the result of a die any player rolled by 1.

cards.flavorText: Summoned for all the wrong seasons.
cards.name: Spirit of the Season
cards.originalText: When Spirit of the Season enters the battlefield, it gains haste if it's summer. Put a +1/+1 counter on it if it's autumn. You gain 5 life if it's winter. If it's spring, search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.
cards.text: When Spirit of the Season enters the battlefield, it gains haste if it's summer. Put a +1/+1 counter on it if it's autumn. You gain 5 life if it's winter. If it's spring, search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Strategy, Schmategy
cards.originalText:
Roll a six-sided die. Strategy, Schmategy has the indicated effect.
1 — Do nothing.
2 — Destroy all artifacts.
3 — Destroy all lands.
4 — Strategy, Schmategy deals 3 damage to each creature and each player.
5 — Each player discards their hand and draws seven cards.
6 — Repeat this process two more times.

cards.flavorText: "Here on going is heck the what?"
cards.name: Topsy Turvy
cards.originalText: The phases of each player's turn are reversed. (The phases are, in reverse order, ending, postcombat main, combat, precombat main, and beginning.) As long as there are more than two players in the game, the turn order is reversed.

rulings.text: Topsy Turvy was printed upside down relative to the Magic card back on the other side. Topsy Turvy is “upright” when the artwork is oriented at the bottom. That’s the joke! For more information, see http://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/get-it-unhinged-edition-part-1-2017-08-14

cards.text:

cards.name: Water Gun Balloon Game
cards.originalText:
As Water Gun Balloon Game enters the battlefield, each player puts a pop counter on "0."

Whenever a player's pop counter hits "5," that player creates a 5/5 pink Giant Teddy Bear creature token and resets all pop counters to "0."
